net.floodlightcontroller.core.internal

Class OFSwitch

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.floodlightcontroller.core.internal.OFSwitch
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IOFMessageWriter, IOFSwitch, IOFSwitchBackend

    public class OFSwitch
extends java.lang.Object
implements IOFSwitchBackend
    This is the internal representation of an openflow switch.

        public java.util.Collection<org.projectfloodlight.openflow.protocol.OFPortDesc> getEnabledPorts()
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitch
        Get list of all enabled ports. This will typically be different from the list of ports in the OFFeaturesReply, since that one is a static snapshot of the ports at the time the switch connected to the controller whereas this port list also reflects the port status messages that have been received.
        Specified by:

      • processOFPortStatus

        public OrderedCollection<PortChangeEvent> processOFPortStatus(org.projectfloodlight.openflow.protocol.OFPortStatus ps)
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitchBackend
        Add or modify a switch port. This is called by the core controller code in response to a OFPortStatus message. It should not typically be called by other floodlight applications. OFPPR_MODIFY and OFPPR_ADD will be treated as equivalent. The OpenFlow spec is not clear on whether portNames are portNumbers are considered authoritative identifiers. We treat portNames <-> portNumber mappings as fixed. If they change, we delete all previous conflicting ports and add all new ports.
        Specified by:
        processOFPortStatus in interface IOFSwitchBackend
        Parameters:
        ps - the port status message
        Returns:
        the ordered Collection of changes "applied" to the old ports of the switch according to the PortStatus message. A single PortStatus message can result in multiple changes. If portName <-> portNumber mappings have changed, the iteration order ensures that delete events for old conflicting appear before before events adding new ports

      • processOFTableFeatures

        public void processOFTableFeatures(java.util.List<org.projectfloodlight.openflow.protocol.OFTableFeaturesStatsReply> replies)
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitchBackend
        Add or modify a switch table. This is called by the core controller code in response to an OFTableFeaturesReply message. It should not typically be called by other Floodlight modules or applications.
        Specified by:
        processOFTableFeatures in interface IOFSwitchBackend

      • getSortedPorts

        public java.util.Collection<org.projectfloodlight.openflow.protocol.OFPortDesc> getSortedPorts()
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitch
        This is mainly for the benefit of the DB code which currently has the requirement that list elements be sorted by key. Hopefully soon the DB will handle the sorting automatically or not require it at all, in which case we could get rid of this method.
        Specified by:
        getSortedPorts in interface IOFSwitch
        Returns:

        Specified by:

      • comparePorts

        public OrderedCollection<PortChangeEvent> comparePorts(java.util.Collection<org.projectfloodlight.openflow.protocol.OFPortDesc> ports)
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitchBackend
        Compute the changes that would be required to replace the old ports of this switch with the new ports
        Specified by:
        comparePorts in interface IOFSwitchBackend
        Parameters:
        ports - new ports to set
        Returns:
        the ordered collection of changes "applied" to the old ports of the switch in order to set them to the new set. If portName <-> portNumber mappings have changed, the iteration order ensures that delete events for old conflicting appear before before events adding new ports

        public OrderedCollection<PortChangeEvent> setPorts(java.util.Collection<org.projectfloodlight.openflow.protocol.OFPortDesc> ports)
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitchBackend
        Replace the ports of this switch with the given ports.
        Specified by:
        setPorts in interface IOFSwitchBackend
        Parameters:
        ports - new ports to set
        Returns:
        the ordered collection of changes "applied" to the old ports of the switch in order to set them to the new set. If portName <-> portNumber mappings have changed, the iteration order ensures that delete events for old conflicting appear before before events adding new ports

      • getMaxTableForTableMissFlow

        public org.projectfloodlight.openflow.types.TableId getMaxTableForTableMissFlow()
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitchBackend
        In OF1.3+ switches, the table miss behavior is defined by a flow. We assume the default behavior is to forward to the controller, but not all tables need that behavior if a limited set of tables are used. So, we can cap the number of tables we set this flow in to reduce clutter in API output and to reduce memory consumption on the switch. This gets the TableId cap set for this particular switch.
        Specified by:
        getMaxTableForTableMissFlow in interface IOFSwitchBackend

      • setMaxTableForTableMissFlow

        public org.projectfloodlight.openflow.types.TableId setMaxTableForTableMissFlow(org.projectfloodlight.openflow.types.TableId max)
        Description copied from interface: IOFSwitchBackend
        In OF1.3+ switches, the table miss behavior is defined by a flow. We assume the default behavior is to forward to the controller, but not all tables need that behavior if a limited set of tables are used. So, we can cap the number of tables we set this flow in to reduce clutter in API output and to reduce memory consumption on the switch. This sets the TableId cap set for this particular switch. If the max desired is higher than the number of tables this switch supports, the max table supported will be used: set_max_table = max_supported <= max ? max_supported-1 : max
        Specified by:
        setMaxTableForTableMissFlow in interface IOFSwitchBackend
        Returns:
        the TableId set as the highest

        Returns:
